head.ce:title: Revisiting signal transducer and activator of transcription 3 (STAT3) as an anticancer target and its inhibitor discovery: Where are we and where should we go?

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: As a transcription factor, STAT3 protein transduces extracellular signals to the nucleus and then activates transcription of target genes. STAT3 has been well validated as an attractive anticancer target due to its important roles in cancer initiation and progression. Identification of specific and potent STAT3 inhibitors has attracted much attention, while there has been no STAT3 targeted drug approved for clinical application. In this review, we will briefly introduce STAT3 protein and review its role in multiple aspects of cancer, and systematically summarize the recent advances in discovery of STAT3 inhibitors, especially the ones discovered in the past five years. In the last part of the review, we will discuss the possible new strategies to overcome the difficulties of developing potent and specific STAT3 inhibitors and hope to shed light on future drug design and inhibitor optimization.

ce:section.ce:para: STAT3 is a dual-functional protein with ability of signal transduction and activation of gene transcription. Under physiological conditions, it mediates cell proliferation, differentiation, apoptosis, survival, immune function, angiogenesis and other important cellular processes in response to stimulation of a large number of cytokines and growth factors [1,2]. Normal STAT3 signaling is tightly controlled in standard cellular response. However, constitutive STAT3 activation occurs frequently in a variety of human cancers [3â5]. Overwhelming preclinical and clinical evidences demonstrate the pivotal involvement of STAT3 in promoting several hallmarks of cancer [6â8]. Furthermore, STAT3 is found persistently hyperactivated and associates with resistance to chemotherapy and poor prognosis [6â8]. Aberrant STAT3 activity is also observed in immune cells where it restrains anti-tumor immune response through upregulation of immunosuppressive factors and downregulation of immune activation factors [9,10]. On the other hand, although the persistent activation of STAT3 can be attributed to multiple mechanisms [11,12], the mutation of STAT3 itself has recently drawn wide attentions, owing to the fact that more and more mutations in key active sites have been found in cancer patients. The gain-of-function STAT3 mutations closely associate with the occurrence and progression of cancer [13]. Taken together, numerous studies have demonstrated the validation of STAT3 as an anticancer target and development of potent and specific STAT3 inhibitors is still an attracting approach for cancer therapy.

The STAT family is comprised of seven proteins including STAT1, STAT2, STAT3, STAT4, STAT5Î±, STAT5Î² and STAT6 [14] Among them, STAT3 was originally discovered as an acute-phase response factor (APRF) in IL-6 inflammatory response process [14]. It consists of about 770 amino acids with a relative molecular weight of 88Â kDa. Four isoforms of STAT3 have been identified in mammals including STAT3Î±, STAT3Î², STAT3Î³ and STAT3Î´. They usually contain six structural domains (Fig.Â 1 A), including the N-terminal domain, coiled-coil domain, DNA-binding domain, linker domain, SH2 domain and transactivation domain, each of which play different roles in the process of signal transduction and activation of gene transcription. In addition, STAT3 has two important phosphorylation sites, Tyr705 and Ser727(Fig.Â 1). The N-terminal domain performs important functions for STAT3 dimers nuclear translocation and subsequently cooperative DNA binding [15â17]. The coiled-coil domain mediates the interaction of STAT3 with other proteins. The DNA binding domain recognizes specific DNA sequence and then forms the STAT3-DNA complexes. The linker domain is involved in the interaction with cellular transcriptional system. The SH2 domain is crucial for STAT3 binding to the phosphotyrosine residues on the kinase receptors, resulting in the following phosphorylation of STAT3 by tyrosine kinase. The SH2 domain is also critical for STAT3 dimerization via reciprocal interactions between the phosphorylated Tyr705 within one monomer and the SH2 domain within the other monomer. There are three important solvent-accessible sub-pockets in the SH2 domain which can be targeted by small-molecule inhibitors (Fig.Â 1B), and will be discussed detailly in section 5. The critical phosphorylation sites, Tyr705 and Ser727 are essential for STAT3 activation and subsequent dimerization.

STAT3 can be activated by the binding of a variety of cytokines, hormones and growth factors to their cell surface receptors (Fig.Â 1C). In canonical Janus kinase (JAK)-STAT3 signaling pathway, ligands bind to the receptors on the cell membrane and lead to receptors dimerization [18,19]. Then, receptor dimers recruit and activate JAK kinase proteins in the cytoplasm. Activated JAKs phosphorylate the tyrosine residue of receptors where inactive STAT3 binds through the SH2 domain. Subsequently JAKs phosphorylate Tyr705 residue of STAT3 and activate STAT3. Nonreceptor tyrosine kinases, Src and Abl, are also able to activate STAT3 [20,21]. Activated STAT3 proteins form dimers and then translocate from the cytoplasm to the nucleus where the dimers bind to STAT3-specific DNA-response elements and regulate the expression of STAT3 target genes. The downstream genes may mediate cell proliferation, apoptosis, differentiation, survival, immune response, angiogenesis and other important physiological processes.

Tyrosine phosphorylation and subsequent dimerization of STAT3 are critical steps in the canonical JAK-STAT3 signaling pathway. Although phosphorylation at Tyr705 is required for dimerization in most case, there are evidences that STAT3 enable to dimerize in the absence of phosphorylation of Tyr705 in the non-canonical STAT3 signaling pathway [22]. Specifically, acetylation at Lys685 of STAT3 is reported to stabilize STAT3 dimers and to be necessary for its full transcriptional activity [23]. Besides homodimerization, STAT3 can also form heterodimers with STAT1 and therefore translocate into the nucleus to regulate expression of target genes [24]. Apart from regulating gene expression as a transcription factor, STAT3 may also play functions through epigenetic regulation such as DNA methylation and chromatin modification [25,26]. In addition to the well-known cytoplasmic location, STAT3 is also detected in mitochondrial fractions and contributes to regulation of mitochondrial electron transport chain (ETC) [27]. Taken together, STAT3 signaling can be activated by distinct mechanisms and exerts multiple physiological functions in normal cells. Moreover, STAT3 signaling is tightly controlled by negative regulatory factors, such as the suppressors of cytokine signaling (SOCS) and the protein tyrosine phosphatases (PTPs), to maintain transient activation state under physiological conditions [28].

ce:section.ce:section-title: Constitutive STAT3 activation in human cancers
ce:section.ce:para: Aberrant STAT3 activation occurs frequently in a variety of solid tumors and hematological malignancies. A large number of studies show the critical role of persistent STAT3 activation in the context of malignant transformation and tumorigenesis. In this section, we will briefly review its suggested roles in cancer and its potential as an anticancer target.

Incidence of aberrant STAT3 signaling has been observed in solid tumors [7] including breast, melanoma, head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC), prostate, colon, pancreatic, renal, ovarian, and lung. One of the first evidence of constitutive STAT3 activation was found in breast cancer model [29]. Hyper-active STAT3 signaling was subsequently detected in breast cancer cell lines, tumor models, and patient samples [30]. Aberrant STAT3 activation promotes proliferation and survival of breast cancer cell and enhances resistance to chemotherapy by upregulating Bcl-XL, Bcl-2 and surviving proteins [29,30]. Constitutive STAT3 activation also participates in maintenance of the melanoma phenotype and tumor metastasis and promotes cancer cell growth and survival by up-regulating of Bcl-XL and Mcl-1 [31,32]. In addition, persistent activated STAT3 could upregulate vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) and promotes the melanoma invasion and metastasis [33]. Abnormally active STAT3 is also detected in HNSCC and regulates downstream genes that control cell growth and survival of HNSCC, including cyclin D1, VEGF and Bcl-XL [34,35]. It is also reported that STAT3 is constitutively activated with a high frequency in prostate cancer cells [36]. Studies reveal that abnormal STAT3 activation upregulates the expression of antiapoptotic proteins, such as Bcl-XL and Mcl-1 in prostate cancer [36,37]. Persistent STAT3 activation is found to be promoted by IL-6 and VEGF and upregulates expression of downstream genes in brain cancer [38]. These studies indicate that targeting constitutively active STAT3 may be a feasible strategy for cancer therapy.

In addition to the observation of hyperactive STAT3 in solid tumors, constitutive STAT3 activation is also found in a variety of hematological malignancies including multiple myeloma, anaplastic large T cell lymphoma (ALCL), EBV-related Burkittâs lymphoma, herpes simplex virus saimiri-dependent T cell lymphoma, cutaneous T cell lymphomas and leukemias [39,40]. The aberrant STAT3 signaling is involved in multiple processes of hematopoietic cancer. STAT3 can also be activated by various cytokines to promote deterioration of blood cancers, such as IL-6 in multiple myeloma, IL-12 in cutaneous T cell lymphoma and erythropoietin (EPO) in erythroleukemia [10]. Moreover, deficiency of negative regulators in STAT3 signaling such as SOCS may also contribute to constitutive activation of STAT3 in these tumors [41]. Except for critical role in cancer progression, some studies suggest STAT3 is a positive contributor in the early phases of carcinogenesis and required for cancer stem cell status maintenance [42â45]. Therefore, inhibition of STAT3 may block carcinogenesis at early stage of cancer development and is beneficial for cancer prevention.

Besides upregulation of upstream stimulation and lack of negative regulation leading to constitutive STAT3 activation, mutations of STAT3 itself also contribute to persistent activation of STAT3 signaling. With the application of next generation sequencing technology in clinic, more and more STAT3 mutations are figured out in human cancers [13]. Some studies have revealed the closed association between STAT3 mutants and hematopoietic cancer progression [46,47]. Several mutational hotspots of STAT3, including Y640F (17%), D661V (9%), D661Y (9%), N647I (4%) and D661H (1%), have been detected in T-cell large granular leukemia (T-LGL) patients and chronic lymphoproliferative disorders of NK cells (CLPD-NK) patients [46]. These mutations are located in SH2 domain that mediates the dimerization and activation of STAT3. Functional experiments inÂ vivo and inÂ vitro indicate that mutant STAT3 can continuously activate and regulate downstream target gene expression [46,47]. Compared with wild-type STAT3, STAT3 mutants induce higher expression of target genes and thereby promote cancer progression. Studies of mutant STAT3 in T-LGL reveals a positive relationship between STAT3 mutants and the stages of cancer development [46]. Two highly frequent mutants K658Â N and Y640F are also found in inflammatory liver tumors [13]. Another study indicates that over-expression of STAT3 Y640F mutant in mouse bone marrow transplantation model can induce myeloid malignancies [48]. In addition, activating STAT3 mutations are also detected in the DNA binding domain and the coiled-coil domainï¼which is also associated with carcinogenesis and cancer progression, although the frequency of mutations is much lower [47]. For example, M206K mutation, which locates in the coiled-coil domain and promotes STAT3 signaling activity and cell proliferation, is identified in diffuse large B cell lymphoma (DLBCL). The frequency of mutation is higher in subset of DLBCLs with CD30 expression and associates with poor prognosis [49,50]. STAT3 is predominantly mutated in hematopoietic neoplasms, especially in T-LGL leukemia (30â40% mutation rate), but not significantly mutated in other cancers beyond T-LGL, CLPD-NK and DLBCL [10,46â50]. But given the closed relationship between activating STAT3 mutation and cancer progress, especially in relation to the poor prognosis, development of specific inhibitors targeting STAT3 mutants might benefit these hematopoietic cancer with higher rate of mutations.

Immunotherapy has been considered a promising strategy for cancer treatment and has received significant progress over the last 30 years. On the other hand, besides pivotal roles in proliferation, invasion, angiogenesis and metastasis of human cancers, STAT3 is also reported to play critical functions in modulation of tumor microenvironment and immune response, and has been considered as a promising target to improve the efficacy of cancer immunotherapy.

Takeda etÂ al. firstly identified STAT3 as a negative regulator of T helper 1 (Th1) cell immune activity in 1999 [51]. Lack of STAT3 activity in macrophages and neutrophils enhances Th1 activity in mouse model. Many tumor-derived factors, such as IL-6, IL-10 and VEGF, which activate STAT3, also show hyper-activity in tumor-associated immune cells. Such positive feed-forward loop supports the constitutive activation of STAT3 in tumor environment, and then persistently activated STAT3 inhibits both innate and adaptive immunity. Moreover, STAT3 promotes Th17 maturation and differentiation by regulating IL-17 production [9,51]. Th17Â cells can be converted into regulator T cells, thereby promoting tumor-associated immunosuppression. Hyper-activated STAT3 also promotes secretion of IL-10 and TGF-Î² in regulatory T cells, therefore inhibiting the function of CD8+ T cells [52]. Moreover, STAT3 activation can globally suppress maturation of dendritic cells (DCs), a highly differentiated monocyte, which contributes to the antigen-presenting process in human immune system [53]. It has been demonstrated that tumor-induced immune related factors in the tumor microenvironment play a critical role for immune response. Highly overexpressed STAT3 also downregulates the expression of IFNÎ², IFN-Î³, IL-12, CD80, CD86, CC-chemokine ligand 5 (CCL5) and CXC-chemokine ligand 10 (CXCL-10) in tumor microenvironment to help tumor cells escape from immune system [52,54,55].

The programmed death ligand 1 (PD-L1) and programmed cell death protein 1 (PD-1) axis is one of the most important checkpoint pathways in immune response system. It suppresses the effector functions of activated T cells and autoimmune responses through T-cell exhaustion. Targeted therapies using anti-PD-L1 and anti-PD-1 antibodies against components of this pathway have been shown promising outcomes to reduce tumor burden in cancer patients. A great number of studies indicate that multiple oncogenic signaling pathways including JAK/STAT3 strictly regulate the expression of PD-L1 in cancer cells [56â59]. It is also reported that STAT3 binds to the PD-L1 promoter and regulates its expression transcriptionally. For example, binding STAT3 to the gene promoter region is required for the PD-L1 gene expression, which was verified by gel electromobility shift and chromatin immunoprecipitation assays in T cell lymphoma cells [58]. STAT3 also upregulates expression of PD-L1 in nasopharyngeal carcinoma driven by Epstein-Barr virus [59]. Moreover, activating STAT3 mutations promote expression of PD-L1 in NKTL cells, while STAT3 inhibition and silencing decreases PD-L1 expression [56]. Given the role of STAT3 in immune activity and the correlation of PD-L1 and STAT3 signaling pathway, the combination of immunotherapy, especially PD-1/PD-L1 antibodies, and STAT3 specific inhibitors might be a promising therapeutic approach for cancer treatment. In summary, STAT3 signaling promotes cross-talking between tumor cells, dendritic cells, and diverse immune-cell subsets including tumor-associated regulatory T cells to form an immunosuppressive network. Multilevel interactions between STAT3, tumor cells and immune cells facilitate immunosuppression, tumorigenesis and cancer progression. STAT3 also contributes to immunosuppression through regulation expression of PD-L1, IDO1 and secretion of immunosuppressive factors [55â57,60,61]. Therefore, inhibition of STAT3 may overcome immunosuppression in the tumor microenvironment and enhance efficacy of cancer immunotherapy.

As a transcription factor, STAT3 molecules transduce extracellular signals from the surface membrane to the nucleus where they bind to specific DNA substrate and promote the transcription of target genes. Therefore, two major distinct strategies have been employed to develop inhibitors to block STAT3 signaling and activity in the past two decades [62,63]. One is the development of inhibitors targeting upstream molecules, such as JAKs and Src; the other one focuses on directly targeting STAT3 protein. Since the upstream molecules are involved in intricate signaling pathways, their inhibitors may elicit rather broad spectrum of kinase inhibition and lack specificity for STAT3 signaling pathway, thereby resulting in off-target toxicities. On the other hand, the upstream kinases inhibitors of STAT3 signaling pathway have been reviewed in detail in the previous reviews [62,63], so this part will not be duplicated here.

Direct STAT3 inhibitors can be classified into different categories in view of their distinct mechanisms of action, including inhibition of STAT3 phosphorylation, dimerization, nuclear translocation, and inhibition of STAT3 DNA-binding activity. In order to simplify the sum-up of these inhibitors and shed light on the future STAT3 inhibitor discovery, two groups will be classified based on their opposite binding modes of action: noncovalent STAT3 inhibitors and covalent ones. Noncovalent inhibitors block STAT3 signaling via noncovalent electrostatic interactions (such as hydrogen bond, van der Waals attraction, ionic bond, and hydrophobic effect) with STAT3, which can be rapidly dissociated. Whereas covalent inhibitors inactivate STAT3 by forming covalent bonds with nucleophilic residues (such as cysteine) within STAT3, and show longer residue time and stronger inhibitory activities than noncovalent ones.

Since STAT3 dimerization and subsequent DNA-binding are the critical steps in the whole signaling pathway, direct STAT3 inhibitors are mainly designed and developed to target the SH2 domain or the DNA binding domain. Based on the different binding sites, noncovalent STAT3 inhibitors can be classified into two categories: (1) noncovalent STAT3 inhibitors targeting the SH2 domain; (2) noncovalent STAT3 inhibitors targeting the DNA binding domain. In addition, there are also a large of researches involving development of potential STAT3 inhibitors, whose binding sites are not clarified so far, and we will combine them together as other noncovalent STAT3 inhibitor.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Noncovalent STAT3 inhibitors targeting SH2 domain
ce:section.ce:para: As described in section 2, the SH2 domain comprises of three sub-pockets that can be targeted by small molecule STAT3 inhibitors (Fig.Â 1B), including: (1) the phosphorylated tyrosine 705 (pTyr705)-recognition site (labeled as the pY sub-pocket); (2) a side-pocket (labeled as pY-X sub-pocket); (3) the Leu706-recognition site (labeled as pY+1 sub-pocket). The pY pocket is composed of Lys591, Ser611, Glu612, Ser613, and Arg609. In the process of STAT3 homodimerization, pTyr705 residue within one monomer forms hydrogen bonds and salt bridges with above residues within the other monomer, especially Arg609 and Ser611 among others. The pY+1 pocket that is surrounded by Thr620, Trp623, Lys626, Gln635, Val 637, Ile659, is mainly hydrophobic, as indicated by the lack of hydrogen bond formation in this region. The pY-X pocket is specific for STAT3 and associates with the selectivity of STAT3 inhibitors, which consists of typical hydrophobic residues deep inside the pocket, such as Glu594, Arg595, Ile597, Ile634. However, it is noteworthy that the interactions with these three sub-pockets do not contribute equally to the binding affinity of STAT3 inhibitors, of which a large portion of the binding energy arises from the interaction with the pY sub-pocket. So many research groups are striving to discover more potent and drug-like scaffolds to target this sub-pocket. Therefore, noncovalent STAT3 inhibitors targeting the SH2 domain will be assorted based on their different fragments binding to the pY sub-pocket.

The early identified STAT3 inhibitors targeting SH2 domain are peptides and peptidomimetics [62]. McMurray group [64â68], and Wang team [69,70] made significant advances on the discovery of potent peptidomimetic STAT3 inhibitors incorporating a phosphorylated tyrosine residue. Since these researches had been reviewed in the previous publications [62,71] at great length, they will not be included in this perspective. Compared with peptides or peptidomimetics, small molecules have the advantages of high cell permeability, good bioavailability and strong physicochemical stability. So small molecule STAT3 inhibitors were developed based on the phosphate group, which forms hydrogen bonds and salt interactions with the pY sub-pocket.

Turkson etÂ al. [72] initially identified a phosphopeptide with the sequence of PY*LKTK (Y* representing phosphorylated tyrosine), derived from the dimerization interface of STAT3, to disrupt STAT3 dimerization, whose IC50 value for inhibition of STAT3 DNA-binding activity inÂ vitro was determined to be 235Â Î¼M by an electrophoretic mobility shift assay (EMSA). Analysis of alanine scanning mutagenesis and deletion verified and simplified the active sequence to tripeptides [72], such as PY*L (compound 1, Fig.Â 2 ) and AY*L (compound 2, Fig.Â 2), with the IC50 values of 182 and 217Â Î¼M respectively in inhibiting STAT3 DNA-binding activity inÂ vitro. With the aim of reducing tripeptide characteristics and size, the leads were modified to produce a series of small molecules by replacing the proline or alanine with aromatic groups [73]. Substitution of proline with 4-cyanobenzoate afforded the representative compound 3 (ISS610, Fig.Â 2), which improved the inhibition of STAT3 DNA binding activity with the IC50 of 42Â Î¼M. However, compound 4 (Fig.Â 2), the non-phosphorylated form of compound 3, had no effect on STAT3 DNA-binding activity inÂ vitro, demonstrating the importance of interactions between phosphate group and the pY sub-pocket.

Molecule modeling studies on compound 3 showed that only two of the three sub-pockets within SH2 domain mentioned above were accessed (pY and pY-X), with the pY+1 sub-pocket unoccupied. In order to address this problem and improve its binding affinity with STAT3, trisubstituted oxazoles or thiazoles (compound 5, Fig.Â 3 ) were designed with two hydrophobic substituents targeting the relatively hydrophobic sub-pockets (pY+1 and pY-X) and the phosphate group binding to the pY site with the help of flexible ligand-docking studies [74]. Comprehensive structureâactivity relationship (SAR) study demonstrated that the oxazole derivatives showed more promising inhibitory activities than thiazoles, taking the examples of compound 6 and 7 (Fig.Â 3) with the IC50 values of 33 and 58Â Î¼M respectively for the inhibition of STAT3 DNA-binding activity inÂ vitro. Compound 6 also displayed cytotoxic activities against human breast cancer cell line (MDA-MB-231, EC50Â =Â 180Â Î¼M) and NIH-3T3/v-src cells (EC50Â =Â 120Â Î¼M), both of which harbor constitutively active STAT3, while compound 6 did not show cytotoxic activity in NIH-3T3 cells even at the concentration of 1000Â Î¼M. Coordination of the sizes of R1 and R2 in compound 5 attracted necessary attentions, since attaching two steric fragments to the central oxazole core was not well tolerated. Incorporation of cyclohexylphenyl in compound 6 and naphthyl in 7 into oxazole afforded compound 8 (Fig.Â 3), which displayed dramatically reduced STAT3 DNAbinding inhibitory activity with the IC50 of 255Â Î¼M.

Considering the inherent low cellular membrane permeability of phosphate derivatives, dramatic efforts were made to identify drug-like small molecule STAT3 inhibitors with enhanced cell permeability and metabolic stability. In the aid of in silico structure-based high throughput virtual screening, Turkson group identified a hit (compound 9, Fig.Â 4 ) using an inÂ vitro STAT3 DNA-binding assay and EMSA analysis [75]. Compound 9 is characterized by a salicylic acid moiety that is a known mimetic of phenylphosphate group. Compound 9 inhibited STAT3 DNA-binding activity inÂ vitro with an IC50 of 86Â Î¼M, and induced apoptosis in breast and hepatocellular cancer cells that contain constitutively activated STAT3. Since the O-tosyl group (OTs) of compound 9 is usually recognized as a good leaving group, it is proposed that the inhibitory activities demonstrated inÂ vivo might be derived from its covalent modification of STAT3 protein. Therefore, researches on verifying this hypothesis were conducted by Gunning etÂ al. [76], which will be discussed in the next section.

Given the moderate inhibitory activity of compound 9 against STAT3, Gunning group launched a rational drug design and discovery program to modify and optimize this small molecule with the purpose of obtaining more potent and selective STAT3 inhibitors based on the salicylic acid scaffold [77]. Firstly, they replaced the oxygen atom of the OTs with a nitrogen atom to stabilize the tosyl group and obtained compound 10 (Fig.Â 4). Gold docking studies revealed that the resulting tosylamide moiety accessed to the pY-X site and salicylic acid group reasonably targeted to the pY sub-pocket. But the inhibitory activity of compound 10 to disrupt STAT3 DNA binding was reduced to a negligible level with the IC50 value above 300Â Î¼M by EMSA. Incorporating a methyl to the NH of the tosylamide (compound 11, IC50Â >Â 300Â Î¼M) was also unsuccessful. Owing to the fact that compound 11 only targeted two of the three sub-pockets (pY and pY-X) within the SH2 domain, making one more contact with the third pocket (pY+1) may improve the inhibitory potency. Therefore, modifications of the NH of the amide group by incorporating hydrophobic moieties were conducted in order to make hydrophobic interactions with the pY+1 sub-pocket. It was revealed that benzyl substituted compound 12 (Fig.Â 4) displayed some recovery in activity (IC50Â =Â 292Â Î¼M, EMSA). Replacement of the benzyl in compound 12 with para-(phenyl)benzyl furnished compound 13 (Fig.Â 4), which inhibited STAT3 DNA binding activity with the IC50 value of 115Â Î¼M. This enhancement might be due to additional hydrophobic interaction with the pY+1 sub-pocket as expected. Para-(tert-butyl)benzylated compound 14 (Fig.Â 4) showed slight decrease in activity (IC50Â =Â 194Â Î¼M) compared to compound 13. Substitution of para-(tert-butyl)benzyl with especially hydrophobic para-cyclohexylbenzyl afforded compound 15 (Fig.Â 4), and led to considerable improvement in activity (IC50Â =Â 35Â Î¼M, EMSA) [78]. Moreover, compound 15 exhibited no significant inhibition of STAT1:STAT1 complex at 50Â Î¼M and no effect on STAT5:STAT5 complex even up to the concentration of 300Â Î¼M, as determined by EMSA analysis. Taken together, these data validated the practicability of the approach that forming hydrophobic interactions with the pY+1 sub-pocket via incorporating additional groups to the amide NH of compound 10 enhanced its STAT3 inhibitory activity and selectivity.

In the other aspect, Gold docking studies revealed that tosyl group of compound 15 occupied to the hydrophobic pY-X sub-pocket which associates with the selectivity of STAT3 inhibitors, and Gunning group optimized this moiety to discover more potent and selective salicylic acid based analogues of compound 15. It was revealed that replacement of sulfonamide moiety of compound 15 with hydrophobic substituents afforded more potent inhibitors, and especially that incorporating a pentafluorophenyl sulfonamide substituent to the salicylic acid moiety resulted in the most active inhibitor (compound 16, Fig.Â 4) [79]. Compound 16 directly bond to STAT3 protein with the binding affinity (KD) of 504Â nM as determined by surface plasmon resonance (SPR) analysis, and inhibited STAT3 DNA binding activity with an IC50 value of 6.8Â Î¼M by EMSA. Compound 16 selectively inhibited growth, survival, migration, and invasion of STAT3-dependent tumor cells, such as NIH3T3/v-Src, MDA-MB-231, Panc-1, DU145, and A549Â cells, but lacked cellular inhibitory activity in a range of nontarget cells, including normal NIH3T3, TE-71, NIH 3T3/v-Ras or A2780S cells without aberrantly active STAT3. When administered via intravenous injection (3Â mg/kg) or oral gavage (3Â mg/kg), compound 16 significantly inhibited growth of human breast (MDA-MB-231) and nonâsmall-cell lung (A549) tumors in xenograft models, without obvious signs of toxicity [80].

Further efforts were also made by Gunning group to optimize the pharmacokinetics (PK) properties of compound 16 via optimizing its salicylic acid fragment [81â84]. It was revealed that removing the hydroxyl group of the salicylic acid in compound 16 was well tolerated and led to a more potent STAT3 inhibitor (compound 17) [81]. Compound 17 displayed a strong interaction with STAT3 (KDÂ =Â 300Â nM) in the SPR assay and preferentially inhibited STAT3 DNA binding activity with the IC50 of 3.9Â Î¼M in the EMSA analysis, and showed no effects against STAT1 and STAT5 DNA binding activities in the parallel assay. In addition, compound 17 potently inhibited cell viability of U251MG and MDA-MB-231 with the IC50 values of 1.9 and 4.5Â Î¼M respectively, and inhibited growth of mouse xenografts of human glioma (U251MG) and breast (MDA-MB-231) tumors at 3Â mg/kg.

Recently, Turkson group took an iterative medicinal chemistry program to optimize the N-methylglycinamide linker of the lead compound 16 and 17 to further improve their inhibitory potency and physicochemical properties [85]. Substitution at the glycine methylene group of lead 16 with methyl afforded two enantiomers, and the R-configuration 18 (Fig.Â 4) improved the inhibitory activity against STAT3 DNA-binding inÂ vitro moderately with the IC50 of 3.0Â Î¼M, while the corresponding S-configuration 19 (Fig.Â 4) displayed somewhat lower potency (IC50Â =Â 5.0Â Î¼M) than 18. In addition, compound 18 strongly inhibited the viability of human metastatic melanoma C8161, 1205LU, and C81-61Â cell lines harboring constitutively active STAT3, while demonstrated relatively weaker potency against the immortalized human normal melanocyte AR7119. Further SAR exploration with different substitutions at the methylene position of 16 confirmed that R-configuration analogues consistently exhibited higher activity than the S-analogues. Based on this observation, further modification of the benzoic acid moiety of 18 was conducted to improve STAT3 inhibitory potency. It was revealed that a single fluorine substitution at the 3-position of benzoic acid group (compound 20, Fig.Â 4) led to 2-times enhancement in inhibitory potency against STAT3 DNA binding activity inÂ vitro with the IC50 of 1.8Â Î¼M and inhibited the MDA-MB-231Â cell growth with the IC50 of 3.9Â Î¼M. Considering that the alanine residue based compounds are more prone to metabolic N-demethylation, a further modification to the alanine linker was performed by joining the two methyl groups of compound 20 to form a new Pro-linker. The representative analogue 21 (Fig.Â 4) showed equivalent STAT3 DNA-binding inhibitory activity inÂ vitro (IC50Â =Â 2.4Â Î¼M) compared to 20, but indeed displayed much improved microsomal metabolic stability.

Another analogue, compound 24 [88], was developed by displacing the acetyl group with sulfonamide and showed higher selectivity for STAT3 than compound 22 and 23. Computer modeling and simulation showed that sulfonamide targeted to the pY sub-pocket and formed at least 3 hydrogen bonds with Arg609, Ser611, and Ser613, while compound 24 lacked interactions with pY-X site or pY+1 site. As we mentioned above that the pY-X site is unique to STAT3, thus recovery or optimization of the binding interactions with this site may enhance the selectivity for STAT3. In the meantime, the drug-like properties of compound 24 with poor bioavailability is still defective, which need further optimization. Based on the above two considerations, Li etÂ al. [89] firstly simplified the anthraquinone moiety to 1,4-naphthoquinone with the aim of improving its bioavailability, while keeping sulfonamide group because of its multiple interactions with the pY sub-pocket. And then a second group was incorporated to the C6 position of 1,4-naphthoquinone, which was proposed to bind to the pY-X sub-pocket and improve selectivity for STAT3. With the help of in silico site-directed fragment-based drug design strategy and computer docking, compound 25 (Fig.Â 5) was designed and identified. Cell-based assay revealed that compound 25 reduced the cell viability of human sarcoma cell lines with low IC50 (0.52Â Î¼M for U2OS; 0.55Â Î¼M for RH30; and 1.39Â Î¼M for RD2). Western blot assays showed that compound 25 inhibited STAT3 phosphorylation in a dose-dependent manner in both RH30 and EW8 cell lines. Fluorescence polarization (FP) assay [90] validated that compound 25 bond to STAT3 SH2 domain. Compound 25 also suppressed inÂ vivo tumor growth in human breast cancer MDA-MB-231 mouse xenograft. Taking advantage of advanced multiple ligand simultaneous docking, Yu etÂ al. also designed compound 26 (Fig.Â 5) [91], as an orally bioavailable STAT3 inhibitor, which presented superior drug-like properties and selectivity compared with the above analogues. Compound 26 directly and selectively targeted STAT3 SH2 domain with an affinity (Ki) of 440Â nM, as determined by the FP assay. In contrast, no direct binding between 26 and STAT1/5 proteins was observed. Compound 26 exhibited promising cytotoxic activity against human breast cancer cell line, MDA-MB-231, with the IC50 of 0.7Â Î¼M, which is 184-fold lower than that for MCF-10A normal breast epithelial cells (IC50Â =Â 128.9Â Î¼M). Compound 26 had desirable aqueous solubility and its oral bioavailability was measured to be 44.7% by PK study. Following-up inÂ vivo studies on the antitumor efficacy demonstrated that 60% of MDA-MB-231 tumor weight and 73% of S180 tumor weight were shrunk upon treatment with compound 26Â at the dose of 5Â mg/kg orally administrated for 21 days. In the meantime, no damage to major organs was observed and body weight increased normally after treatment of compound 26.

Compound 27 (Napabucasin, Fig.Â 5) is reported to be an orally available cancer cell stemness inhibitor and exhibits excellent anticancer activities against diverse solid and hematologic cancers [92]. Several clinical trials of compound 27 are performed to evaluate its promising efficacies in patients with varying cancer types, both as a monotherapy and combination therapy [93]. Even though the exact target of compound 27 has yet to be fully elucidated, it is revealed that the anticancer activities of compound 27 is closely associated with the inhibition of STAT3 signaling pathway. It potently inhibited STAT3 phosphorylation, blocked nuclear translocation and decreased STAT3-mediated gene transcription. Compound 27 can be recognized as a promising lead compound to generate novel STAT3 inhibitors and subsequent objective optimization on compound 27 may focus on the improvement of specificity for STAT3 to avoid the off-targets cytotoxicities. Another natural product, compound 28 (Shikonin, Fig.Â 5) [94], harboring a naphthoquinone scaffold, is also reported to exhibit STAT3 inhibitory potency, but inhibits Focal adhesion kinase (FAK) and Src activation at the same time. In order to optimize the selectivity for STAT3, Yang etÂ al. [95] primarily explored the interaction mode of compound 28 with STAT3 by virtual simulation and discovered that it mainly occupied the pY-X and pY sub-pockets and made hydrogen bonds with Lys591, Glu594 and Ile634. The simulation results also suggested that modification of the hydroxyl group on the side chain may further enhance the binding affinity and selectivity toward STAT3. Therefore, a scaffold growth strategy was employed to generate a series of compound 28 analogues, taking the example of the lead compound 29 (Fig.Â 5) which formed more hydrogen bonds with Gln635 and Ser636. Further inÂ vitro investigation furnished the more efficient compound 30 (Fig.Â 5), which showed high anti-proliferative activity for MDA-MB-231Â cells with the IC50 value of 1.81Â Î¼M and induced cell apoptosis in MDA-MB-231Â cells dose dependently. In addition, compound 30 inhibited constitutive STAT3 activation, transcriptional activity, nuclear translocation and downstream target genes expression in MDA-MB-231Â cells, with no inhibitory effect on activation of STAT1 and STAT5. Furthermore, inÂ vivo studies demonstrated that compound 30 notably suppressed the MDA-MB-231Â cells xenografted tumor growth without obvious side effects.

Although naphthoquinone analogues are designed as potent STAT3 inhibitors and induce significant anticancer responses, the undesirable properties [96] of these naphthoquinone derivatives are less explored. Therefore, more detailed mechanistic studies and multiple evaluations of drug-like properties for these compounds are needed for further drug discovery.

The COX2 inhibitor, compound 31 (Celecoxib, Fig.Â 6 ), was identified by Li and coworkers as STAT3 inhibitor by performing virtual screening of compounds from FDA approved drugs library [97]. Compound 31 could inhibit STAT3 phosphorylation induced by IL-6, whereas displayed little effect on the phosphorylation of STAT1 induced by interferon-Î³. Meanwhile, compound 31 inhibited the viability of human colon cancer cell (HCT-116) with the IC50 value of 43.3Â Î¼M. However, docking studies showed that it only targeted two sub-pockets of the SH2 domain with the phenylsulfonamide group binding to the pY site and the tolyl moiety occupying the pY-X site. In order to improve the inhibitory activity of compound 31, compound 32 and 33 (Fig.Â 6) were identified through fragment-based drug design, via introducing the third substituents targeting to the pY+1 sub-pocket. Docking models demonstrated improved binding affinities for compound 32 (â8.6Â kcal/mol) and 33 (â9.2Â kcal/mol) compared to that of compound 31 (â6.9Â kcal/mol). In the meantime, more potent inhibition of HCT-116 viability was observed for compound 32 (IC50Â =Â 9.7Â Î¼M) and 33 (IC50Â =Â 10.1Â Î¼M).

Given the above sulfamide analogues expressing high selectivity for STAT3, Kong group [98] also designed a series of tripedal phenylsulfonamide derivatives in order to identify STAT3 inhibitors with better selectivity and improved drug-like properties, represented by the most potent compound 34 (Fig.Â 6). Molecular docking studies revealed that the phenylsulfonamide fragment of compound 34 bond to pY sub-pocket via hydrogen bond interactions with Arg609 residue, while the perfluorophenyl group occupied pY-X sub-pocket and the isopropylphenyl fragment targeted to the pY+1 sub-pocket. Compound 34 inhibited the proliferation of HCT-116Â cells with the IC50 of 6.66Â Î¼M, and markedly suppressed STAT3 phosphorylation in a dose-dependent manner, with little influence on STAT1 and STAT5 phosphorylation. In addition, compound 34 inhibited the colony formation of HCT-116Â cells and induced the apoptosis. Moreover, inÂ vivo anticancer efficacy study showed that compound 34 effectively suppressed the tumor growth of HCT-116 xenograft, with no significant change in body weight at the dose of 20Â mg/kg.

In order to identify selective STAT3 inhibitors over STAT1, a structure-based virtual screening of a commercially available compound library followed by a luciferase-containing promoter assay was performed by Pudlo etÂ al. [99] and resulted in the identification of a prospectively selective STAT3 inhibitor, compound 35 (TableÂ 1 ), which displayed 53.9% inhibitory effect at 50Â Î¼M on STAT3 transcriptional activity with 5-fold selectivity over STAT1. Molecular docking displayed that the aminotetrazole group occupied the pY sub-pocket and formed hydrogen bonds with residues forming the sub-pocket (such as Lys591, Arg609, Ser611 and Ser613), and in the meantime that the benzyl ether moiety bond to the pY+1 site. Optimization of the para-methyl on the phenyl moiety revealed that incorporation of nitro group in 36 increased activity on STAT3 and selectivity over STAT1. Compound 36 blocked STAT3 transcriptional activity with an IC50 value of 25.7Â Î¼M, and decreased proliferation of B9 myeloma cell line and MDA-MB-231 in a dose dependent manner. Keeping the nitro group confirmed at the para-position of phenyl, bioisosteres of tetrazole were screened to optimize the inhibitory activity and selectivity toward STAT3. Replacing the tetrazole of 36 with a carboxy acid in 38 reduced both STAT3 and STAT1 inhibitory activity to a large extent. Interestingly, non-ionizable aldehyde (39) and alcohol (40) derivatives demonstrated the same range of inhibition as 36, but lost selectivity over STAT1. The cyanamide analogue 41 and phthalimide analogue 37 showed enhanced STAT3 inhibitory activity, but unfortunately lacked selectivity over STAT1.

Asai etÂ al. identified compound 42 (Fig.Â 7 ) as a novel STAT3 SH2 domain inhibitor by virtual screening using DOCK program with the crystal structure of STAT3 [100]. STAT3-dependent luciferase reporter gene assay validated compound 42 as a STAT3 direct inhibitor with 99% inhibitory potency at 100Â Î¼M. Fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET) assay showed that incubation of the HEK293Â cells with compound 42 prior to IL-6 stimulation suppressed FRET signals. Treatment MDA-MB-468 with compound 42 led to a reduction in amplification of the c-Myc promoter revealed by a chromatin immunoprecipitation (Chip) assay. In contrast, a truncated analogue removing the 2-phenyl, compound 43, lacked these activities. Compound 42 selectively inhibited DNA-binding activity of STAT3, with no effect on DNA binding activity of other STAT subtypes. Furthermore, compound 42 effectively suppressed the growth of human lymphoma cells in a SCC-3 subcutaneous xenograft model without visible toxicity via oral administration. Docking model of compound 42 with STAT3-SH2 domain illustrated that the 1,3,4-oxadiazolyl occupied the pY+1 sub-pocket and that the 2-phenyl group accessed to the pY-X sub-pocket, which explains the abolished inhibitory activity of compound 43 (Fig.Â 7) toward STAT3. However, it is noteworthy that compound 42 still suffers from the lack of interactions with the pY sub-pocket, which contributes mainly to the inhibitory activity of STAT3 dimerization as well known. Therefore, incorporation of one more appropriate group into compound 42 to recover this interaction may further improve its inhibitory effect on STAT3.

Based on the structure characteristics of STAT3-SH2 domain, Lin etÂ al. [101] designed a novel series of small molecule STAT3 inhibitors, taking the example of compound 44 (TableÂ 2 ), with the carboxylate moiety as a mimetic of phosphate to access the pY sub-pocket and di-trifluoromethyl substituted benzene designed to form hydrophobic interactions with the pY-X sub-pocket. A combination of urea and peptidyl fragment was used to link the above two groups to capture hydrogen bonds with the residues (such as Lys591, Ser636, and Gln635) located in the space between pY and pY-X sub-pockets. It was revealed that compound 44 inhibited STAT3 phosphorylation in rhabdomyosarcoma cell lines (such as RD2, RH28 and RH30) harboring constitutive STAT3 and also prevented IL-6 induced STAT3 phosphorylation and nuclear translocation. It was also observed that compound 44 treatment remarkably reduced colony formation and migration ability of the three cancer cells. Compound 44 also displayed measurable inhibitory activity against human pancreatic (PANC-1, HPAC and SW1990) and breast (MDA-MB-231) cancer cell lines with the IC50 values in the range of 17.4â24.7Â Î¼M. Hydrolysis the carboxylate ester of 44 to free carboxylic acid 45 resulted in IC50 values greater than 100Â Î¼M unexpectedly [102]. Replacement of the isopropyl (R2 group) in 44 with bulkier groups, such as isobutyl in 46 and tert-butyl in 47, demonstrated much increased inhibitory activity across all tested cell lines. While an aromatic phenyl group as R2 substituent (compound 48) was well tolerated with increased inhibitory activity compared to 44.

In order to facilitate the identification of potent STAT3 inhibitors that can be used in clinic, Turkson group prepared a 3D quantitative structure activity relationship (QSAR) pharmacophore model firstly, and subsequent computational docking analysis based on the QSAR model identified 2, 6, 9-trisubstituted purine scaffolds as a potential skeleton to occupy the pharmacophore plot [103]. Forty-seven 2, 6, 9-trisubstituted purine derivatives were prepared and SPR evaluation demonstrated over one-third of them showing high binding affinity to STAT3 (KDÂ <Â 10Â Î¼M), including the representative compounds 49â52 (TableÂ 3 ). GOLD docking model showed that various appendages at R and the cyclohexylbenzyl substituent accessed to two predominantly hydrophobic sub-pockets (pY-X and pY+1, respectively), and that the polar N9-carboxylic acid occupied the polar pY sub-pocket. Further evaluation in inÂ vitro EMSA analysis revealed that these compounds inhibited STAT3 DNA binding activity with IC50 values of 27â84Â Î¼M. Furthermore, compounds 49â52 selectively suppressed viability of human prostate (DU145), breast (MDA-MB-231) and pancreatic (Panc-1) cancer cells, and v-Src-transformed mouse fibroblasts (NIH3T3/v-Src) that harbor aberrant STAT3 activity, with no effect on NIH3T3 cells. It should be noted that the activity difference between SPR analysis and EMSA analysis for compounds 49â52 may be owe to the presence of off-targets in the nuclear extracts utilized in the EMSA assay.

Using a virtual screening approach by docking compounds to the three sub-pockets (pY, pY-X and pY+3 residue binding site) of the STAT3 SH2 domain, Tweardy group [104] discovered a lead compound 53 (C188, Fig.Â 8 ), which exhibited an IC50 of 20Â Î¼M in a FP assay and inhibited IL-6-mediated phosphorylation of STAT3 with an IC50 of 73Â Î¼M. Compound 53 also abrogated activated STAT3 nuclear translocation with an IC50 of 39Â Î¼M, and induced apoptosis of MDA-B-468 with EC50 of 0.73Â Î¼M. Computational docking studies revealed that the (carboxymethyl)thio moiety of compound 53 bond to the pY site and formed hydrogen bonds with Arg609, Glu612 and Ser611, while the hydroxyl-oxygen of the benzoic acid moiety formed a hydrogen bond with the amide-hydrogen of Glu638, an important residue which locates in the pY+3 binding site. Based on the chemical scaffold of 53, Tweardy etÂ al. conducted similarity screening and identified a more potent compound 54 (C188-9, Fig.Â 8), which bond to STAT3 with the KD of 4.7Â nM determined by the MicroScale Thermophoresis (MST) experiment [105,106]. Compound 54 efficaciously inhibited granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF)âinduced STAT3 phosphorylation in 6 AML cell lines, with the IC50 value of 4.1Â Î¼M in KG-1Â cells and 8.3Â Î¼M in NB-4Â cells, but did not alter the level of total STAT3 protein. Compound 54 also potently induced apoptosis in AML cell lines, with the EC50 value of 6Â Î¼M in GDM-1Â cells and 8Â Î¼M in Kasumi-1Â cells via inhibition of STAT3 activity. Its inhibitory effect on the clonogenicity was also observed in primary AML cells. In addition, treatment of nude mice bearing UM-SCC-17B squamous carcinoma xenografts with 54 showed that it inhibited tumor growth at the dosage of 100Â mg/kg/day. More importantly, compound 54 was well tolerated, and showed good oral bioavailability. Given its potential PK and PD characteristics, compound 54 is being tested in phase I clinical trial (NCT03195699) to determine its safety, adequate dose and anticancer activity in patients with advanced cancers.

Compound 55 (OPB-31121, Fig.Â 8) is a JAK2/STAT3 signaling pathway inhibitor developed by Otsuka Pharmaceutical Co., Ltd, which displayed dramatically high binding affinity to the STAT3 SH2 domain with KD value of 10Â nM determined by isothermal titration calorimetry (ITC) experiments [107]. While it is noteworthy that compound 55 occupies a distinct binding site within the STAT3 SH2 domain compared to the above descripted STAT3 SH2 domain inhibitors, confirmed by inÂ vitro binding assays and competition assays. The unique binding mode of compound 55 with STAT3 also operates within the context of cellular biological activity. It was revealed that compound 55 completely inhibited the phosphorylation of Tyr705 at the doses of 5â10Â nM in DU145 and LNCaP cell lines, and showed highly cytotoxic activity against LNCaP and DU145Â cells with the IC50 values of 18Â nM and 25Â nM, respectively. Based on its efficacy in preclinical models, Phase I/II clinical trials have been conducted in patients with advanced solid tumors. It demonstrated a favorable toxicity profile with Grade 1/2 treatment-related adverse events, but was characterized with poor PK profiles with high variability and low bioavailability. Making matters worse, maximum concentration (Cmax) of compound 55 after accumulation was over 100-fold lower than active concentrations in mouse tumor xenograft models, leading further clinical investigation of 55 being halted.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Noncovalent STAT3 inhibitors targeting DNA-binding domain
ce:section.ce:para: As another critical step in the STAT3 signaling pathway, dimerized STAT3 binding to specific DNA-response elements and thereby regulating the transcription of target genes is essential for cellular responses. Therefore, inhibition of STAT3 signaling pathway by targeting DNA-binding domain is considered another viable approach and efforts are made to develop potential inhibitors.

By using drug repositioning strategy, Ding and coworkers identified compound 56 (Niclosamide, TableÂ 4 ), an FDA-approved anthelmintic drug, which displayed signiï¬cant inhibitory effect on STAT3-induced luciferase activity in Hela cells with the IC50 of 0.25Â Î¼M and suppressed Tyr705 phosphorylation level of STAT3 in Du145Â cells without affecting the total STAT3 protein level [108]. Compound 56 dramatically inhibited the proliferation and colony formation of Du145Â cells with IC50 values of 0.7 and 0.1Â Î¼M, respectively, and induced G0/G1 phase arrest and apoptosis in Du145 dose dependently. An immunofluorescence assay showed that STAT3 nuclear translocation induced by EGF was successfully inhibited by treatment of compound 56. Western blotting study revealed that compound 56 effectively inhibited the transcription function of STAT3 protein leading to decrease of the protein levels of downstream target genes, such as cyclin D1, c-Myc, and Bcl-XL. Mechanism of action studies revealed that compound 56 did not demonstrate inhibition against JAk1, JAK2, Src, EGFR, VEGFR, and PDGFR etc. Compound 56 was unable to bind to the SH2 domain in the FP assay. However, Reigan group revealed that compound 56 targeted the DNA-binding domain of STAT3 via a modified DNA-binding ELISA assay incorporating recombinant STAT3 protein, with an IC50 value of 1.93Â Î¼M [109].

In order to discover new molecules with ideal pharmacokinetic profile, a series of novel O-alkylamino tethered derivatives (compounds 57â61, TableÂ 4) of compound 56 have been developed with remarkably enhanced aqueous solubility by Zhou group [110]. 2-Aminoethyl substituted compound 59 (HJC0152) displayed near 3000-times improvement in water solubility and exhibited similar inhibitory potency compared to compound 56. Compound 59 also inhibited STAT3 promoter activity, inhibited cell cycle, and promoted apoptosis in MDA-MB-231Â cells. Furthermore, compound 59 significantly suppressed MDA-MB-231 xenograft tumor growth inÂ vivo at a dose of 25Â mg/kg, which is even more efficacious than compound 56Â at 75Â mg/kg. In addition, compound 59 significantly suppressed human HNSCC tumor growth (derived from the SCC25Â cell line) [111], glioblastoma tumor growth (established from U87Â cell line) [112] and gastric cancer tumor growth (derived from the MKN45Â cell line) [113] at a dose of 7.5Â mg/kg, with no significant change in body weight. Incorporation of 4-piperidinyl to compound 56 led to dramatically improvement in cytotoxic activity against breast cancer cell lines MCF-7 and MDA-MB-231 for compound 57. However, methylation of compound 57 or dimethylation of compound 59 resulted in remarkable loss of cytotoxic activities, maybe due to the abolished ability of hydrogen bond donor for compounds 58 and 60. The O-alkylamino length also played an important role in modulating inhibitory activity of this series compounds verified by the lost activity of compound 61 compared to compound 59.

In order to discover small molecular compounds that selectively inhibit STAT3 DNA-binding activity, Zhang etÂ al. performed structure-based virtual screening of approximately 200,000 compounds to the STAT3 DNA-binding domain, and successfully identiï¬ed compound 62 (InS3-54, Fig.Â 9 ) [114]. Compound 62 inhibited STAT3 DNA-binding activity in a dose-dependent manner with an IC50 of 20Â Î¼M in the EMSA assay and inhibited STAT3-dependent luciferase reporter expression in MDA-MB-231Â cells with an IC50 of 13.8Â Î¼M in the luciferase assay. The growth and survival of cancer cells harboring constitutively active STAT3 (A549, H1299, MDA-MB-231, and MDAMB-468) were sensitive to treatment of compound 62 with IC50 of 3.2â5.4Â Î¼M in the cytotoxicity assay. In addition, compound 62 inhibited migration of both A549 and MDA-MB231Â cells in dose- and time-dependent manners. However, 62 had no eï¬ect on the level of total STAT3 or basal level of Tyr705-phosphorylated STAT3, and had no inhibition on IL-6 stimulated phosphorylation of STAT3, indicating that it unlikely bond to the SH2 domain. Furthermore, quantitative reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) analysis of mRNAs confirmed that the expression of STAT3 downstream target genes (cyclin D1, survivin, VEGF, MMP2, MMP-9, and Twist) were all decreased following compound 62 treatment in both A549 and MDA-MB-231Â cell lines. In addition, Wells group [115] developed a new FP assay to screen molecules that prevent the STAT3 DNA-binding using a STAT3127â688 protein and a Bodipy-DNA conjugate as the fluorescent probe, and validated that compound 62 was able to inhibit the STAT3: DNA association with the IC50 value of 21.3Â Î¼M. Nevertheless, it is still necessary to note that the higher activity of 62 in inhibiting cancer cell survival than inhibiting DNA binding and luciferase reporter expression may arise from its potential oï¬-target eï¬ect, which needs to be validated.

In an effort to discover STAT3 inhibitors targeting the DNA binding domain with improved potency and specificity, Zhang and coworkers performed an extensive structure and activity-guided optimization of compound 62 and identified compound 63 (A18) with improved specificity and potency [116]. The specificity of compound 63 was confirmed in colony-formation assay and it was revealed that compound 63 reduced colony-formation efficiency of hematopoietic progenitor cells from STAT3+/+ mice, but did not appear to have any significant effect on the colony-formation of hematopoietic progenitor cells from STAT3â/â mice. However, compound 62 not only reduced the proliferative activity of STAT3+/+ hematopoietic progenitor cells, but also reduced the colony formation of the cells from STAT3â/âmice. EMSA assay demonstrated that compound 63 inhibited the DNA-binding activity of STAT3 in a dose-dependent manner, but did not affect the DNA-binding activity of STAT1. Compound 63 was also more effective than compound 62 in inhibiting cancer cell survival (A549, MCF10A1, and MDA-MB-231). Further pharmacological investigation revealed that compound 63 enabled to inhibit cancer cell (A549 and MDA-MB-231) migration and invasion and decrease the expression of STAT3 downstream target genes (cyclin D1, surviving, matrix metalloproteinase-9, and VEGF) in A549 and MDA-MB-231Â cell lines, and inhibit the binding of STAT3 to its target sequence on chromatin DNA in situ. Compound 63 also significantly suppressed xenograft tumor growth of A549 at a dose of 200Â mg/kg, with little adverse effect on mouse body weight.

Ligand-based virtual screening of the Specs chemical library in combination with 3D shape- and electrostatic-based drug design approach by Huang and coworkers lead to the identification of a new STAT3 inhibitor, compound 64, based on the pharmacophore of compound 62 and 63 [117]. Compound 64 showed inhibitory activity on survival of H1299Â cells with an IC50 of 8.1Â Â±Â 4.1Â Î¼M and inhibited STAT3 binding to the DNA domain with a ki value of 3.92Â Î¼M in microscale thermophoresis assay. Compound 64 also enabled to suppress survival of cisplatin-resistant ovarian cancer cell (SKOV3/DDP) with an IC50 of 14.7Â Â±Â 2.4Â Î¼M compared to the IC50 of 3.7Â Â±Â 0.7Â Î¼M for ovarian cancer cell (SKOV3) and induced apoptosis in SKOV3/DDP cells. Of particular note is that compound 64 possess unsaturated ketone which may react with cysteine residues of STAT3, while it is not discussed whether it can covalently modify STAT3 in the publication.

Compound 65 (Fig.Â 9) was identified to be an inhibitor of IL-6/STAT3 signaling pathway by Li group [118] via virtual screening, which displayed inhibitory effect on STAT3-induced luciferase activity in HepG2 cell with an IC50 of 3.567Â Î¼M. Compound 65 showed above 6-fold selectivity over IFN-Î³/STAT1 signaling pathway, but did not demonstrate inhibitory activity toward TNF-Î±/NF-KB signaling. Taking compound 65 as a potential lead structure, Li discovered a better inhibitor, compound 66 (Fig.Â 9), whose inhibitory activity was enhanced 3-times compared with compound 65, with an IC50 of 1.16Â Î¼M. It also inhibited cell viability of MDA-MB-468 with an IC50 of 16.06Â Î¼M. However, the binding site of compound 66 is still needed to be verified.

A benzyloxyphenyl scaffold 67 (TableÂ 5 ) was identified by Li etÂ al. [119] as novel STAT3 inhibitor through virtual screening, which displayed inhibitory activity on STAT3 transcription with an IC50 of 26.68Â Î¼M in the luciferase assay and inhibited cell viability of MDA-MB-468 with an IC50 value of 18.83Â Î¼M as determined using MTT assay. Removing the chlorine atom at C-5 improved the luciferase inhibitory activity from 26.68Â Î¼M to 7.71Â Î¼M (67 vs 68). Incorporation of a fluorine atom (compound 70) to C-5 position of 68 was tolerated while the bromine atom (compound 71) was detrimental to the inhibitory activity. Replacement of hydroxyl group within compound 67 by sulfonamide led to compound 72 with slightly reduced IC50 value of 35.67Â Î¼M for luciferase activity. Moving the chlorine from C-5 to C-3 (compound 69) resulted in a significant enhanced luciferase activity with an IC50 value of 1.38Â Î¼M.

As exemplified in Fig.Â 3, compound 9 was identiï¬ed from the NCI chemical libraries by taking advantage of structure-based virtual screening into the STAT3 SH2 domain, and was proposed to show its inhibitory efficacy inÂ vivo as a result of covalent modification of STAT3 and/or other off-targets. STAT3 consists of twelve cysteine residues (Cys108, 251, 259, 328, 367, 418, 426, 468, 542, 550, 687, and 712) with distinct potential reactivities toward electrophiles. Cys251, 328 and 550 are buried in the interior of STAT3 and are not solvent exposed. Cys108, 259, 418, 426, and 712 are exposed to solvent. Cys468 is solvent exposed in the absence of STAT3 specific DNA binding partner, whereas Cys367, 542, and 687 are less exposed residues.76 Therefore, multiple chemical biology approaches were employed by Gunning and coworkers to explore its potential reactivity toward STAT3 and elucidate its mechanism of action (MOA).76 An HPLC-based assay revealed that compound 9 reacted rapidly with glutathione, a nucleophile including cysteine, via SN2 nucleophilic substitution reaction mechanism. Incubation of STAT3 with compound 9 and thereby LC-MS/MS analysis revealed that compound 9 covalently modified Cys108, Cys259, Cys367, Cys542, Cys687 of STAT3, all of which are solvent exposed. A DANSYL fluorescent tagged compound 9 induced a time dependent increase in fluorescent signal of the STAT3 protein, labeled three STAT subtypes (STAT1, STAT3 and STAT5) non-specifically, and alkylated multiple intracellular proteins in MDA-MB-231Â cell lysates. These data demonstrated that compound 9 was not an optimal chemical probe for studying STAT3-related cell biology and needed more structural optimization to provide more specific covalent inhibitory effect on STAT3.

Compound 73 (Stattic, Fig.Â 10 ) was identified as a STAT3 SH2 domain inhibitor via HTS of a diverse chemical library [120]. Compound 73 disrupted STAT3 dimerization with the IC50 value of 5.1Â Î¼M in the FP assay and inhibited active STAT3 DNA binding activity at 10Â Î¼M in the EMSA assay. The breast cancer cell lines, MDA-MB-231 and MDA-MB-435s, were induced apoptosis after the treatment of compound 73Â at 10Â Î¼M. While it was also revealed that compound 73 displayed its inhibitory effect on STAT3 SH2 domain in a time-, temperature-, and dithiothreitol-dependent manner, indicating its covalent irreversible interaction with STAT3. Saturation of the double bond of the vinyl sulfone moiety afforded compound 74 (Fig.Â 10) and led to loss of activity in the FP assay, supporting the Michael addition reaction between compound 73 and nucleophilic residues (such as cysteine) of STAT3. Since there are twelve cysteine residues present in STAT3, mass spectrometry methods were developed to investigate the reaction sites of STAT3 with compound 73. Buettner etÂ al. observed that a mass increase of 1690Â Da for phosphorylated STAT3 after treatment with compound 73 [121]. The mass difference indicated that eight equivalents of compound 73 were incorporated to one equivalent of phosphorylated STAT3 protein. A similar research was conducted to research the alkylation reaction between compound 73 and un-phosphorylated STAT3Î²tc by Heidelberger etÂ al. [122] It was revealed that nine compound 73 molecules were added to one inactivated STAT3Î²tc covalently and four or five of the nine modified residues were confirmed as cysteines. Furthermore, Cys468 and Cys542 were confirmed not to react with compound 73, indicating that a degree of reaction selectivity between cysteine residues of STAT3. As a control, bovine serum albumin (BSA) including cysteines was also alkylated by compound 73, indicating that the molecular lacked selectivity over other proteins.

To identify novel potent STAT3 inhibitors with new scaffolds and improved drug-like properties, Zhou et el. designed a series of novel diversified analogues of compound 73 based on the privileged fragments from the reported representative STAT3 inhibitors [123]. Structural hybridization of 2-phenylquinoline-4-caboxylic acid amide of compound 42 and benzo[b]thiophene 1,1-dioxide (BTP) of compound 73 generated compound 75 (Fig.Â 9), while compound 76 (Fig.Â 10) was achieved by condensation of 5-chloro-2-hydroxybenzoic acid with 6-amino substituted BTP. Compound 75 significantly inhibited STAT3 promoter activity in MDA-MB-231Â cells at 5Â Î¼M using cell-based transient transfection assay. Furthermore, compound 75 inhibited the growth of breast cancer (MCF-7 and MDA-MB-231) and pancreatic cancer (AsPC1 and Panc-1) cell lines with lower IC50 values (0.10â1.25Â Î¼M) than that of compound 73 (1.32â3.60Â Î¼M, TableÂ 6 ), and suppressed the growth of MDA-MB-231 xenograft tumors inÂ vivo at the dose of 50Â mg/kg, without evidence of adverse toxicities observed. Compound 76 also exhibited significant cytotoxic activity against the above cancer cells with the IC50 values range in 0.91â2.34Â Î¼M (TableÂ 6). Introduction of 3-aminopropyl group to the hydroxy of compound 76 generated compound 77 (Fig.Â 10) and resulted in enhanced cytotoxic effects (IC50Â =Â 0.04â1.97Â Î¼M, TableÂ 6) and drug-like properties [124].

Using structure-based drug design approach, Kong etÂ al. discovered new BTP derivatives by introducing substituted phenylamine to C-6 or C-7 position of BTP scaffold [125]. Comprehensive SAR study revealed that C7-substituted BTP derivatives were more potent than C6-substituted ones. Among them, the most potent compound 78 (Fig.Â 10) exhibited remarkable cytotoxic activity against four cancer cell line (MDA-MB-231, A549, MCF-7, and HCT116) with IC50 values of 0.68, 0.36, 0.75, and 0.33Â Î¼M, respectively. Compound 78 effectively downregulated the overexpressed and IL-6 induced phosphorylation of STAT3, blocked STAT3 mediated DNA binding activity in the EMSA assay, induced apoptosis in MDA-MB-231Â cells dose dependently, and induced significant antitumor responses inÂ vivo. Compound 79 (Fig.Â 10) was designed by incorporation of piperidine through amide bond linkage to the C2 position of BTP, which exhibited a remarkable inhibitory effect on STAT3-induced luciferase activity in HeLa cells [126]. It also inhibited phosphorylation of STAT3 in a dose-dependent manner, and induced the apoptosis in MDA-MB-435s and MCF-7Â cells.

Compound 80 (Galiellalactone, Fig.Â 11 ), a fungal metabolite, was identified to be a IL-6-dependent JAK/STAT3 signaling inhibitor, which inhibited STAT3 dimers binding to their transcriptional DNA elements with the IC50 values of 250â500Â nM, without affecting the Tyr705 and Ser727 phosphorylation of STAT3 [127]. It inhibited the growth of prostate cancer cells (PC-3 and DU145) expressing constitutively activated STAT3 at the dose of 10Â Î¼M, while did not induce apoptosis in LNCaP cells, which lacked STAT3 activity. Compound 80 also inhibited the expression of STAT3-regulated genes and proteins, such as Bcl-XL, Bcl-2, c-myc and cyclin D1 in DU145Â cells [128]. Furthermore, compound 80 signiï¬cantly reduced the tumor growth in DU145 xenograft model.

Since compound 80 includes a reactive Î±, Î²-unsaturated lactone functionality, it has the potential to covalently alkylate the cysteines within STAT3. Incubation of recombinant STAT3 protein with compound 80 and then mass spectrometry analysis demonstrated that three cysteines (Cys367, Cys468, Cys542) were covalently modified [129]. In addition, three more cysteines (Cys251, Cys259, and Cys687) were identified to be alkylated by compound 80Â at higher concentrations. The binding characteristics of compound 80 to STAT3 were also investigated via wash-out experiments and it was revealed that compound 80 bond reversibly to STAT3 and maintained inhibitory activity even after the compound was removed. It is important to note that compound 80 was also reported to inhibit NF-kB and TGF-Î² signaling pathways and was lack of specificity for JAK/STAT3 signaling pathway.

In order to discover potential STAT3 inhibitors that impressively inhibits STAT3-DNA interaction, Williams etÂ al. discovered compound 81 (C48, Fig.Â 11) using virtual ligand screening (VLS) analysis [130]. Biochemical studies revealed that compound 81 inhibited STAT3 DNA-binding activity with an IC50 value of 10â50Â Î¼M, without affecting the DNA-binding affinity of STAT1 even at concentration of 500Â Î¼M in EMSA. Cell-based assays demonstrated that compound 81 inhibited STAT3-induced gene expression in HeLa cells at concentrations of 3â10Â Î¼M and that MDA-MB-468 and MDA-MB-231 underwent apoptosis following incubation with 1â20Â Î¼M of compound 81. Western blot analysis revealed that compound 81 inhibited STAT3 phosphorylation in MDA-MB-468Â cells, with no effect on STAT3 upstream activators such as, JAK1 and JAK2. In addition, compound 81 displayed significant antitumor efficacy in MDA-MB-468 and C3L5 mouse xenograft models at the dose of 200Â mg/kg.

Given that the benzylic carbon (highlighted in red) of compound 81 is potentially reactive and susceptible to be attacked by cysteine residues, site-directed mutagenesis and mass spectrometry were used to determine its MOA [130]. It was found that Cys468 mutated to Ser468 resulted in the recovery of phosphorylation level of C468S mutant STAT3 and that no significant effect of compound 81 on DNA binding activity of C468S mutant STAT3 was observed. Incubation of phosphorylated STAT3 with compound 81 and subsequent LC-MS analysis revealed six residues of STAT3 being modified and one, among others, was confirmed to be Cys468, which locates at the DNA-binding interface.

Compound 82 (Curcumin, Fig.Â 11) is isolated from turmeric and exerts anticancer effects through regulation of a series of intracellular signaling pathways and protein-protein interactions, including JAK2/STAT3 pathway [131]. However, the clinical use of compound 82 as an anticancer therapeutic agent has been limited due to its poor bioavailability and low potency. With the aim of improving its PK profile and anticancer efficacy, several novel analogues of compound 82 were developed. Li etÂ al. displaced the two hydrogens on the middle carbon of 82 with spiro-cyclohexyl to prevent the transformation of diketone to enol form in solution and identified compound 83 (FLLL32, Fig.Â 11) [132], which displayed 25 times higher inhibitory activity targeting STAT3 SH2 domain than compound 82. Kuppusamy etÂ al. identified a new analogue 84 (Fig.Â 11) by substituting the Î²-diketone of 82 with a piperidone link and incorporating fluorine to the phenyl groups, which exhibited more potent anticancer efficacy inÂ vitro than lead 82 [133]. Further optimization of 84 by incorporating N-hydroxy-pyrroline moiety to the piperidone N-terminus of 83 based on the protective nature of the N-hydroxyl group for healthy cells yielded compound 85 (Fig.Â 11), which displayed both anticancer and antioxidant properties [134].

As compound 82â85 include the Î±, Î²-unsaturated carbonyl moiety, all of them have the potential to alkylate STAT3 covalently. Recently Surh etÂ al. investigated the molecular mechanism of 82 in regulating STAT3 signaling and revealed that STAT3 was covalently modified by compound 82 [135]. And multiple chemical biological approaches demonstrated that compound 82 exerted its STAT3 inhibitory activity through direct modifying Cys259. It is noteworthy that curcumin and its analogues have been regarded as pan-assay interference compounds (PAINS) [136], which demonstrate nonspecific activities in multiple modes of assays and display false biological activities for intended targets. On the other hand, overwhelming evidences have indicated their poor PK/PD properties, such as bad chemical stability, undesirable physicochemical properties, and low bioavailability [137]. Hence, these unfavorable drug-like properties should be taken into consideration when curcumin analogues are utilized as STAT3 lead inhibitors for further drug evaluations and developments.

Recently, targeted covalent inhibitors (TCI) [141,142] has emerged as a potentially more efficient strategy to block PPIs [143], as covalent modification of a nucleophilic residue (such as cysteine residue) located at or in the immediate vicinity of PPIs can overcome the above disadvantages of extensive interfaces in the protein binding groove, and provide high-affinity inhibitors with longer residence time and sustained inhibitory activity compared to noncovalent ones. Actually, STAT3 is sensitive toward chemical modification as evidenced by the reported covalent inhibitors that we summarized in section 5.2. However, most of them are identified via HTS or molecular modeling and virtual screening, alkylate several cysteines of STAT3, and lack specificity for STAT3. These features of above STAT3 covalent inhibitors induce potential risks and challenges associated with off-target toxicity concerns. Therefore, development of covalent STAT3 inhibitors to alkylate unique and non-conserved cysteine residue maybe a promising approach to discover potential anticancer therapeutics. As we discussed in section 5.1, plenty of specific non-covalent STAT3 inhibitors have been identified, which can be used as the starting point for the following structure-based covalent inhibitor discovery. Incorporation of electrophiles to these noncovalent congeners to chemically modify unique and non-conserved cysteine, such as Cys687 locating in the SH2 domain, and Cys712 residing in the dimerization interface, may provide specific covalent STAT3 inhibitors with improved potency and acceptable safety profiles.

On the other hand, proteolysis targeting chimera (PROTAC) technology has emerged and refined over the past two decades as a powerful strategy to provide a more complete and lasting inactivation of target protein signaling via degradation of target protein of interest (POI) [144â156]. The PROTACs are bifunctional molecules with one side capable of engaging an E3 ubiquitin ligase, and the other side binding to POI. Unlike the classical noncovalent inhibitors, which directly bind to POI and block signaling relying on occupancy driven approaches, PROTACs play their roles via recruiting an E3 ligase to tag the POI for ubiquitination and subsequent degradation through the proteasome, through an event driven MOA. Therefore, binding affinity is no longer the most critical factor to be considered when it comes to development of potential PROTACs for POI [144]. As previous studies have revealed that STAT3 can be ubiquitin by E3 ligase and degraded by proteasome [157], it should be another promising approach to develop PROTACs for STAT3 based on the reported selective noncovalent inhibitors. It is noteworthy that Wang group [158] reported the first STAT3 PROTAC during the peer review process of this manuscript.

Furthermore, as we described in section 3, several different types of STAT3 mutations have been detected in clinic cancer patients, which show increased phosphorylation and transcriptional activity of STAT3, compared to wild type STAT3. Making matters worse, these mutations, especially the ones in SH2 domains, such as Y640F which change the binding pocket for dimerization in our computer simulation, may promote cancers to become resistant to the specific STAT3 inhibitors targeting SH2 domain which are developed so far. Therefore, besides that it is urgent to develop specific inhibitors of wild type STAT3 to be approved for clinical application in cancer patients, identification of potent and specific inhibitors to combat STAT3 mutations is also an unmet medical need. Fortunately, both TCI and PROTACs have the advantage of combating acquired drug resistance to targeted cancer therapies. Taken together, targeting STAT3 to develop TCI and PROTACs may not only provide potent and specific small molecule inhibitors, but also enable to delay and overcome acquired drug resistance in human cancers, thereby improving therapeutic response in cancers.
